For example, although leaders can take steps to praise those who use prosocial voice, opportunities may arise less frequently for justice-oriented voice given that confidentiality concerns may sometimes limit opportunities for public discussion.

This highlights the potential relevance of explicit protections from retaliation for those considering the use of voice. Explicit policies relating to retaliation have been found to be effective in encouraging whistle-blowing (Miceli et al., 1999; Miceli & Near, 1989; Near et al., 1993). Although retaliation policies are sometimes observed in organizations that offer formal justice-oriented voice mechanisms, whether such policies serve to encourage such voice has not been explicitly examined. More broadly, limited attention has been given to factors that affect the extent to which the employee sees himself or herself as vulnerable to retaliation for exercising voice, particularly voice that is seen as involving substantial risk for the employee.

The need to examine the relevance of such vulnerability to retaliation is particularly relevant given that the literature examining justice-oriented and formal voice has primarily focused on grievance behavior in union settings (e.g., Boroff & Lewin, 1997). Within this context, the union plays a key role in helping to reduce perceptions regarding vulnerability to retaliation. The grievance process itself can be used to raise the costs to management associated with retaliation for exercising voice. However, it is less clear what factors are most influential within the nonunion sector in reducing perceptions regarding vulnerability to retaliation for the use of justice-oriented, formal voice. The roles played by labor market power and procedural protections remain unexplored but offer promising areas for future research.

Perception of long-term safety is another unexplored area of research. Within the nonunion context, is it feasible to encourage certain types of voice among those who are highly dependent on senior managers for future discretionary rewards. For employees who anticipate competing for promotion and discretionary rewards, can organizations reduce perceptions of vulnerability to the point where they would be willing to use justice-oriented, formal voice? Indeed, perhaps that is why previous research has found employees with lower turnover intentions are less likely to use formal justice-oriented voice (Fleishman & Harris, 1962). For such employees, if concerns cannot be resolved via informal processes, will formal voice be seen as too risky, almost independent of organizational policies and initiatives? This, then, suggests the possibility that for justice-oriented, formal voice, characteristics relating to the future employment status of the employee will serve as critical determinants.

A final unexplored area of research relates to whether social media and new communication technologies change how different forms of voice are viewed both by employees and organizations. Such technology has made it increasingly easier for complaints to be registered, even by multiple individuals simultaneously (not always with the complainant’s consent or knowledge, as in the case of forwarded e-mails). It has also made it easier to share suggestions or complaints anonymously, which may be particularly appealing to employees who are concerned about retaliation (Tripp & Bies, 2009). Furthermore, the lack of face-to-face interaction may reduce constraints on the willingness to share information and concerns. As a consequence of communication technology, norms within organizations about the appropriateness of submitting concerns to skip-level managers may be changing (Blair, 2010). New communication norms may reduce the extent to which raising concerns with multiple levels of managers is seen as provocative or an escalation of the conflict. To the extent, then, that organizations rely on emerging forms of media for employee voice (both formal and informal), the impact of the dimensions identified above may be reduced or enhanced as a consequence of changing norms.

We should also consider social media as a form of voice where employees can express concerns about their employer more broadly within the community. Such voice can be characterized as justice oriented in that the employee is seeking to restore justice by using voice as revenge. Harming the reputation and image of the employer in the community may be seen as a way to impose costs on the employer and achieve some level of retributive justice. These forms of voice are particularly relevant in light of a recent ruling by the National Labor Relations Board protecting communication about workplace concerns on social media and in light of the potential for such communication to go viral (Gupta, 2010; Pyrillis, 2010; Tripp & Bies, 2009).

sec.title: Considering the Dark Side of Voice
sec.p: Implicit in much of the literature on voice is the assumption that voice is functional for the organization. As discussed above, the potential exists for workplace voice to allow for information sharing and improved processes as well as to serve as an alternative to more disruptive responses to conflict and perceived unfairness. Understanding the determinants of voice, then, has value if it creates awareness of how barriers to voice can be minimized and how firms can facilitate the usage of voice. It should be noted, however, that although voice is likely to often be functional for organizations, consideration should also be given to the ways in which voice can be counterproductive and what factors may lead to voice that is designed to be counterproductive. As noted above, justice-oriented voice includes voice attempting to rectify perceived mistreatment as well as voice that attempts to restore justice by causing problems for others in the organization. Voice can be used to make baseless allegations or raise concerns that will cause difficulties for the manager involved or the organization more generally. The allegations may be unrelated to actual issues of concern. Indeed, voice in this instance is not used to rectify specific concerns and instead is designed largely to cause embarrassment and irritation or consume resources. Thus, it becomes feasible for voice to be used as a form of revenge or retribution for other actions or decisions that the employee finds objectionable.

The revenge literature suggests that when employees are angered by some action taken by managerial action or treatment, there are likely to be instances where constructive problem solving is not seen as a viable option. How employees will respond to such circumstances varies, with forgiveness cognitions formed in some instances and revenge cognitions formed in others (Bies, Tripp, & Kramer, 1997). These forgiveness and revenge cognitions are, in turn, strongly related to actual forgiveness and revenge behavior (Bradfield & Aquino, 1999). This literature also suggests that employees are sensitive to the costs of engaging in revenge, with forgiveness being pursued more frequently when the costs of revenge are high (Aquino et al., 2006). With regard to the use of voice as revenge, it is likely that employees will be sensitive to the costs. Since the risks and costs associated with using voice often vary with the type of voice, it is likely that differences will be observed in the role of revenge across the forms of voice. For example, with anonymous voice, employees are not held accountable for claims made, allowing for claims that may not be valid or that may not be related to the actual source of employee concern. When organizations introduce systems for anonymous voice, they are reducing the costs associated with one form of revenge. Because the employee has easy access to at least one low-cost mechanism for revenge, he or she is more likely to engage in revenge cognitions and, in turn, more likely to use voice in a way that is designed to be counterproductive.

Other situations exist where voice may be designed largely to be counterproductive, situations where even the costs of counterproductive voice are low. In the unionized sector, the complexity of the collective bargaining contract makes it feasible to identify potential contract violations—violations that are not necessarily of concern to employees. As such, where significant conflict exists, the grievance process can be used to raise concerns about a multitude of possible contract violations—even those that are of little concern to the employees. The nature of the collective bargaining contract and the protections offered to employees within a unionized environment may reduce the perceived costs of using voice as revenge or as a bargaining chip when negotiating about issues of greater concern to employees. Voice as a form of revenge or retribution can also be observed in other contexts as well, even when examining voice that might otherwise be classified as prosocial. Consider situations where the employees see themselves as protected because of the critical nature of their skills or the presence of procedural protections. Once again, if the employee sees few costs associated with using voice, it becomes feasible to use voice as revenge or retribution. This could include voice that challenges a superior purely in an effort to embarrass, or it could include voice that claims mistreatment about issues that do not significantly concern the employee. In all these instances, the motivation is primarily one of revenge and thus, fundamentally, is designed by the employee to be counterproductive.

Although it is important to acknowledge the potential for voice to be used in ways that are designed to be counterproductive, it is also important to acknowledge that little is actually known about the extent to which this occurs or what conditions lead to such voice. The literature on revenge has outlined many factors associated with revenge cognitions and revenge behavior (Aquino et al., 2006; Bies et al., 1997; Bradfield & Aquino, 1999). What remains unclear, however, is how those factors operate within the context of voice, a context where opportunities exist to modify and change managerial behavior that led to the desire for revenge. Also, little is known about the degree to which voice that is designed to be counterproductive is actually harmful to the organization. Although there are inevitably costs associated with the processing and investigation of voice designed to be counterproductive, it remains unclear whether using such voice for revenge ultimately allows for reconciliation. Does the opportunity to restore some sense of justice via the use of counterproductive voice make it easier for the employee to subsequently reconcile with relevant managers? Or does the formation of revenge cognitions and subsequent revenge behavior create a downward spiral, making it more difficult for the employee to subsequently form forgiveness cognitions and engage in reconciliation efforts?

Within the procedural justice literature, voice has been found to enhance fairness perceptions regarding a decision even when the exercise of voice occurred after a decision and was not considered as a decision was being made (Lind et al., 1990). The act of expressing voice has a value-expressive impact. It affirms the individual’s status within the organization (Avery & Quinones, 2002; Platow, Filardo, Troself, Grace, & Ryan, 2006; Tyler & Blader, 2003; Tyler & Lind, 1992). Although such findings highlight the potential for even voice designed to be counterproductive to affect fairness perceptions and the potential for reconciliation, there are limits on our ability to generalize from procedural justice research to the settings being examined here. For example, one form of counterproductive voice discussed here was anonymous, and anonymity may prevent affirmation of status from occurring. Thus, it remains very possible that the formation of revenge cognitions and subsequent revenge behavior make it more difficult for the employee to subsequently form forgiveness cognitions and engage in reconciliation efforts.

In discussing factors that may inhibit or encourage different forms of voice in the workplace, it is important to acknowledge that much remains to be learned about the actual consequences of different forms of voice. How we view initiatives or practices designed to address barriers to voice may well be informed by our understanding of the consequences associated with voice in its various forms. For example, the availability of anonymous voice might be viewed as a viable mechanism by which to address barriers observed with other forms of voice. However, the availability of this form of voice also offers a path for the expression of voice designed to be counterproductive. Whether the organization ultimately benefits from making available such voice mechanisms requires that research also explore the consequences associated with alternative forms of voice.

sec.title: Summary
sec.p: From an organizational perspective, clearly much is likely to be gained from efforts to expand our understanding of what determines the use of alternative forms of voice. In particular, research that examines the underlying dimensions of various forms of voice will serve to help us better understand why employees choose to voice and consequently help us better understand how to broaden the appeal and usage of voice. Such research has the potential to develop an understanding of how leadership behavior and organizational policies and practices might lead to increased use and benefits of workplace voice to organizations. However, important questions are also raised with regard to the consequences of voice, highlighting the need for the literature to include within its focus attention to the link between why voice is used and the impact on subsequent behavior and attitudes.
